abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Village Irrigation
            Rehabilitation Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory. The
            main objectives were achieved, sustainability is likely, the
            impact of the project has been substantial, and both the
            Bank and the Borrower acted satisfactorily. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, the Bank needs to
            provide additional manpower and financial resources to
            achieve the goal of forming or strengthening FOs to ensure
            sustained O&M rehabilitated schemes. Second, it must
            include specific provisions for appropriate baseline
            surveys, and when more than one agency is involved, provide
            for adequate coordination in programs for the evaluation of
            project impact and performance. Third, the formation of
            farmer organizations should come before physical
            rehabilitation. Fourth, farmer cooperation can be enhanced
            by providing them the opportunity to participate in
            rehabilitation activities as paid laborers. Fifth, land
            consolidation should be combined with scheme rehabilitation
            in tank command areas. Sixth, land tenure needs to
            considered in scheme selection. Seventh, the quality of
            physical works and the attention paid by project staff is
            essential for the success of the rehabilitation effort.
            Eighth, monitoring should be used as a management tool to
            reduce implementation problems. Lastly, the initial scheme
            preparation report should include a comprehensive survey of
            agricultural production performance and socio-economic data
            on potential beneficiaries.
